#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Calculate Accident Incident Rate

#Text=The Occupational Safety and Health Administration ( OSHA ) is a regulatory agency of the federal government that ensures , as much as possible , that American workers operate in a safe working environment .
#Text=The organization requires certain businesses to report their statistics concerning accidents , injuries and other incidents that occur while on the job .
#Text=Accidents and incidents are logged on an OSHA 300 form that is usually tracked on a spreadsheet .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Determining If Your Business Must Report Incidents to OSHA
#Text=Count the number of employees in your company .
#Text=If your company had 10 or fewer employees at all times during the previous calendar year , then you do not need to report incidents to OSHA .
#Text=Determine your industry .
#Text=Every business is part of a particular industry or sector .
#Text=Before you can determine whether or not you need to report incidents to OSHA , you need to understand what industry you 're part of .
#Text=Industries are usually defined by broad categories like " Construction , " " IT Services , " " Food Service , " etc.

column1: #Text=Pick a keyword or two that best describes your business .
#Text=You 'll need that for the next step .
#Text=Get the NAICS for your business .
#Text=The NAICS is the North American Industry Classification .
#Text=It 's a 6-digit code that 's used to classify a business .
#Text=The federal government uses the code to maintain statistics about the types of businesses that exist in the United States .
#Text=Visit the NAICS search site .
#Text=Enter a keyword that describes your business in the field in the upper , right-hand corner of the screen , just above the button that reads " 2007 NAICS Search " .

column1: #Text=OSHA still classifies industries based on the older NAICS codes , so you 'll need to use that search instead of the newer , 2012 search .
#Text=Click the " 2007 NAICS Search " button .
#Text=The new page that appears will be a list of NAICS codes and businesses .
#Text=Select the NAICS code that best describes your business .
#Text=For example , if your business is a restaurant and you put " restaurant " in the search field , you 'll see a variety of codes with descriptions that include the word " restaurant . "
#Text=However , the code 722110 is used to classify full service restaurants .
#Text=Determine if your business must report incidents to OSHA using the NAICS .
#Text=Visit OSHA 's website to get the list of exempt types of business based on the NAICS .
#Text=For this step , you 'll only need the first four digits of your NAICS .
#Text=For example , if your NAICS is 722110 , you only need the 7221 portion of the code .
#Text=The OSHA website lists exempt industries by NAICS , sorted in ascending numerical order .
#Text=Just scroll down until you see where your industry code would be located .
#Text=If it 's there , then your business is exempt .
#Text=In this case , you can see that 7221 is listed and therefore full-service restaurants do not need to report incidents to OSHA .

#Text=Keep in mind , you will still need to report incidents to OSHA if you 're requested to do so by OSHA , the Bureau of Labor Statistics , or any other government organization operating under the authority of OSHA .
#Text=Calculating Employee Accidents and Injuries
#Text=Understand the formula for calculating accidents .

#Text=The formula for calculating incidents is the number of recorded accidents in that year multiplied by 200,000 ( to standardize the accident rate for 100 employees ) and then divided by the number of employee labor hours worked .
#Text=So the formula , again , is accident rate=(number of accidents*200,000)/number of hours worked .

#Text=The 200,000 in this formula represents how many hours would be worked by 100 employees , each putting in 40 hours per week over 50 weeks in a year ; OSHA requires the accident rate to be expressed as incidents per 100 employees with maximum straight-time hours .
#Text=Pull the number of accidents and recordable incidents from the OSHA 300 log .
#Text=The OSHA 300 log is what you use to record workplace injuries .
#Text=In that log is a table where you record incidents .
#Text=Simply count the number of lines that you 've filled out in that table to determine the number of recordable incidents .
#Text=Remember , the rate is calculated on an annual basis for OSHA compliance .
#Text=So , you 'll be reviewing data from the previous year to get the rate .
#Text=Total the number of hours worked by all employees during the year in question .
#Text=You 'll need to pull some payroll data for this step .
#Text=For example , if you have 20 employees and they each worked 2,000 hours during the year , then the total number of hours worked is 20 x 2,000 or 40,000 .
#Text=The total number of hours will include overtime hours , but does not include vacation , paid sick leave or holiday pay .
#Text=Multiply the number of recordable incidents by 200,000 .
#Text=For example , if you recorded 2 incidents , then the number is 2*200,000 or 400,000 .
#Text=Divide by the result by the total number of hours worked .
#Text=Take the number from Step 3 and divide it by the number from Step 2 .
#Text=For example , if you had 1 recordable incident out of 10,000 hours worked in a year .
#Text=Your calculation would be 1*200,000 / 10,000 .
#Text=Prepare the monthly average incident rate .
#Text=Many businesses like to track the incident rate as a monthly figure to assist them in meeting annual and quarterly goals .
#Text=Adjust your calculation for each month to reflect the hours worked by all employees for only that month .
#Text=Add the incidents and hours worked from each month and then calculate the incident rate on the totals .
#Text=For instance , if you had 1 January incident over 10,000 hours worked , then your January average incident rate would be ( 1*200,000)/10,000 , or 20 .
#Text=For another example , if you had eight accidents over 400,000 hours worked by employees in a year , you would calculate the accident rate as ( 8*200,000)/400,000 , or 4 .
#Text=Quick Summary
